intro: Magnolia glaucifolia, commonly known as the white magnolia, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its large, white, fragrant flowers that bloom in early spring before the leaves emerge. The leaves are alternate, simple, and have a glossy, dark green upper surface with a pale, waxy underside. The tree typically grows to a height of 15–25 feet and has a rounded, spreading form. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forested areas.
